identificationInfo.description:
The Polish Named Entity Resources have been obtained from existing sources and supplemented with additional language-specific resources acquired from the Web. Whenever appropriate, inflected forms were generated using Morfeusz SGJP generator. The Polish Named Entity Resource data was used in the process of named entity annotation of the National Corpus of Polish (NKJP).
The following hierarchy of names is used: forenames and surnames, city, country, mountain, region and river names, institution names, relational adjectives and inhabitant names stemming from country names, named entity triggers (months, days, positions, etc.)

originalSource.targetResourceNameURI: Aleksandra Kubiak-Sokół and Marek Łaziński, eds. (2007), Słownik nazw miejscowosci i mieszkanców, Wydawnictwo Naukowe PWN, Warszawa. Publications of the Commission for Standardization of Geographic Names outside Polish Frontiers (Komisja Standaryzacji Nazw Geograficznych poza Granicami Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej), freely available at http://www.gugik.gov.pl/komisja/. The Polish Wikipedia (http://pl.wikipedia.org) – source of capitals of administrative units of different countries (http://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stolice_jednostek_administracyjnych), rivers (http://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rzeki_Afryki, http://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rzeki_Azji, etc.), historical regions of Europe (http://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kategoria:Regiony_i_krainy_historyczne_Europy), mountain chains (selected from several Wikipedia categories), adjectives and citizen names stemming from country names (http://pl.wiktionary.org/wiki/Indeks:Polski_-_Panstwa_Swiata). The World Gazetteer (http://www.world-gazetteer.com) – source of the list of 200 biggest Polish cities.
